content: The House and Senate approved conference agreements on defense bills in FY1999, with additional funding of $8.3 billion for various defense-related purposes. The President signed both bills into law on October 17, and an omnibus appropriations bill for FY1999 was approved on October 20 and 21. The annual defense appropriations bill, signed into law on October 21 (P.L. 105-277), allocated funds for various defense-related purposes including intelligence, missile defense, year 2000 fixes, storm damage repairs, purchasing fissile materials from Russia, antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug activities. The majority of the funding is for programs administered by the Department of Defense. The defense appropriations bill allocates funds for defense-related purposes, including intelligence, missile defense, year 2000 fixes, storm damage repairs, purchasing fissile materials from Russia, antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug activities. The bill also provides funds for national defense activities of various agencies, with the Department of Defense receiving the majority of the funding. The Administration's FY1999 budget included $270.6 billion for the national defense budget function, of which $250.8 billion was requested in the defense appropriations bill. The FY1999 national defense budget reflects a White House-congressional agreement for slow growth in defense budget authority, with cuts achieved by reducing military force size and slowing weapons modernization pace. By FY2003, budget authority for national defense will be almost 38% below the level in FY1985. The Quadrennial Defense Review, released in 1997, outlines plans to reduce military force size and slow weapons modernization. By FY2003, active duty end-strength will decrease by 36%.
